text: in Iraq the sectarian lines are drawn
clearly Shiites are prevalent in the
South Kurds numerous in the Northeast
and Sunnis dominant in the western
regions of the country while Baghdad is
a mixture now with Iraq on the verge of
splitting apart along these sectarian
lines the goals of each group on the New
York Times minute Iraq Sunni Heartland
is now under the control of Islamic
militants whose goal is to establish a
strict Islamic state that spans from
Iraq into neighboring Syria but remember
this area was also the base of support
for Saddam Hussein's more secular regime
for now Islamist and Balthus appear to
have made common cause in Baghdad Prime
Minister Nuri al-maliki heads the
shiite-led government the largest group
in Iraq Shiites were brutally repressed
by mr. Hussein and are now desperate to
maintain their control nothing
illustrates the growing Shiite concern
more than friday's extraordinary call to
arms from Iraq stop Shiite cleric this
has allowed Kurdish forces in the
Northeast to seize control of the
disputed city of Kirkuk with its massive
oil reserves Kurds were notoriously
gassed in 1988 by stam Hussein's troops
they now have a nominal alliance with
the Shia government but are far more
interested in establishing their own
state with Kirkuk as the capital
